tit.cmt: 英辞郎 on the WEB、新和英中辞典

sen.j: 神社（じんじゃ）とは、神道信仰に基づいて作られた宗教施設。
sen.e: A Shinto shrine (or Jinja) is a religious institution based on the Shinto religion.
sen.cmt: 神道：英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: A Shinto shrine (or Jinja) is a religious institution based on the Shinto religion.
A Shinto shrine (or Jinja) is a religious institution based on the Shinto religion.

sen.j: 戦前にはいわゆる「国家神道」のことを単に「神社」と称した。
sen.e: Following the end of the war, 'State Shinto' came to be referred to simply as 'Jinja'.
Before the war, 'State Shinto' was referred to simply as 'Jinja'.
Before the war, 'State Shinto' was referred to simply as 'Jinja.'

sen.j: 教会やモスクなどの礼拝するための礼拝堂や教えを広めるための布教所とは性格が異なる。
sen.e: They are different from places of worship or institutions through which to disseminate teachings such as churches or mosques.
sen.cmt: モスク：英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: They are different from places of worship or institutions through which to disseminate teachings such as churches or mosques.
They are different from places of worship or institutions through which to disseminate teachings such as churches or mosques.

sen.j: 現在では参拝用の施設や結婚式の設備などが造られることも多いが元来はその神社の場所に宿る神を祀る祭祀施設である。
sen.e: Nowadays many institutions are constructed for the purpose of prayer or coducting wedding ceremonies, but jinja were originally built to enshrine the Shinto kami that resides on a particular site.
Nowadays many institutions are constructed for the purpose of prayer or conducting wedding ceremonies, but jinja were originally built to enshrine the Shinto kami that resides on a particular site.
Nowadays many institutions are constructed for the purpose of prayer or conducting wedding ceremonies, but jinja were originally built to enshrine the Shinto kami that resides on a particular site.

sen.j: また場所によっては、社殿を海上・山頂・ビルの屋上などに祀ることもある。
sen.e: Depending the location, the main hall (shaden) may be constructed in places such as the sea, the top of a mountain or on the roof of a building.
Depending the location, the main hall (shaden) may be constructed in places such as the sea, the top of a mountain or on the roof of a building.
Depending the location, the main hall (shaden) may be constructed in places such as the sea, the top of a mountain or on the roof of a building.

sen.j: 神社の起源は、磐座（いわくら）や神の住む場所である禁足地（俗に神体山）などで行われた祭事の際に臨時に建てた神籬（ひもろぎ）などの祭壇であり、元々は常設のものではなかった。
sen.e: The temporary primitive shrines and altars constructed for rituals carried out at rocks in which a kami was thought to dwell or kinsokuchi (tabooed land) on which a kami was thought to reside (comonly referred to as Shintaizan) were non permanent.

The primitive shrines and altars such as the himorogi constructed for rituals carried out at rocks in which a kami was thought to dwell or kinsokuchi (tabooed land) on which a kami was thought to reside (commonly referred to as Shintaizan) were non permanent.
sen.cmt: 文末でnon permanentとあるので、temporaryを削除。such as the himorogiを補足。comonly→commonly
sen.e: The primitive shrines and altars such as the himorogi constructed for rituals carried out at rocks in which a kami was thought to dwell or kinsokuchi (tabooed land) on which a kami was thought to reside (commonly referred to as Shintaizan) were non permanent.

sen.j: 元来は沖縄県の御嶽 (宗教)（ウタキ）のようなものだったと考えられる。
sen.e: These are believed to have resembled the Utaki sacred places of Okinawa.
These are believed to have resembled the Utaki sacred places of Okinawa.
These are believed to have resembled the Utaki sacred places of Okinawa.

sen.j: 古代から続く神社では現在も本殿を持たない神社があり、磐座や禁足地の山や島などの手前に拝殿のみを建てているところもある（参考：大神神社、石上神宮、宗像大社）。
sen.e: Shrines remaining from ancient times do not have a main hall (honden) but consist of only a worship hall (haiden) dedicated to the sacred rock, kinsokuchi, mountain or island on which it stands (for example Omiwa-jinja Shrine, Isonokami-jingu Shrine, Munakata Taisha Shrine).

Shrines remaining from ancient times do not have a main hall (honden) but consist of only a worship hall (haiden) dedicated to the sacred rock, kinsokuchi such as mountain or island on which it stands (for example Omiwa-jinja Shrine, Isonokami-jingu Shrine, Munakata Taisha Shrine).
sen.cmt: 原文では"禁足地の"山や島など、となっている。kinsokuchi, mountain or island →kinsokuchi such as mountain or island
sen.e: Shrines remaining from ancient times do not have a main hall (honden) but consist of only a worship hall (haiden) dedicated to the sacred rock, kinsokuchi such as mountain or island on which it stands (for example Omiwa-jinja Shrine, Isonokami-jingu Shrine, Munakata Taisha Shrine).

sen.j: 神社に社殿が設置されるようになる過程には仏教寺院の影響もあるとされる。
sen.e: The incorporation of main halls into Shinto shrines was due to the strong influence of Buddhist temples.
The incorporation of main halls into Shinto shrines was due to the influence of Buddhist temples.
sen.cmt: 原文で、strongとまでは言われていないので削除。
sen.e: The incorporation of main halls into Shinto shrines was due to the influence of Buddhist temples.

sen.j: 神社には常に神がいるとされるようになったのは、社殿が建てられるようになってからと言われている。
sen.e: It is now said that a kami can only become permanently present at a shrine after the construction of a main hall.
It is now said that a kami can only become permanently present at a shrine after the construction of a main hall.
It is now said that a kami can only become permanently present at a shrine after the construction of a main hall.

sen.j: 神社の周りには鎮守の杜と呼ばれる森林があるのが一般的である（都市部などでないこともある）。
sen.e: Shrines are generally surrounded by a forest known as Chinju-no-mori (forest of the village shrine) (not always present in urban areas).
Shrines are generally surrounded by a forest known as Chinju-no-mori (forest of the village shrine) (not always present in urban areas).
Shrines are generally surrounded by a forest known as Chinju-no-mori (forest of the village shrine) (not always present in urban areas).

sen.j: 御神木といわれる名木には、注連縄を結ばれているものもある。
sen.e: A tree referred to as goshinboku is surrounded by a sacred rope called a shimenawa.
sen.cmt: 注連縄：英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: A tree referred to as goshinboku (sacred tree) is surrounded by a sacred rope called a shimenawa.
A tree referred to as goshinboku (sacred tree) is surrounded by a sacred rope called a shimenawa.

sen.j: 神社の入口には、境内と俗界の境界を示す鳥居があり、社殿まで参道が通じる。
sen.e: The entrance to a shrine is marked with a torii to denote the border between the secular world and the sacred world, and from which a path leads to the main hall.
sen.cmt: 鳥居：プログレッシブ和英中辞典
sen.e: The entrance to a shrine is marked with a torii to denote the border between the secular world and the sacred world, and from which a path leads to the main hall.
The entrance to a shrine is marked with a torii to denote the border between the secular world and the sacred world, and from which a path leads to the main hall.

sen.j: 参道のそばには身を清めるための手水舎（手洗所）、神社を管理する社務所などがある。
sen.e: At the side of the path is a purification trough (temizuya) where visitors cleanse themselves and the office that administrates the shrine (shamusho).
At the side of the path is a purification trough (temizuya) where visitors cleanse themselves and the office that administrates the shrine (shamusho).
At the side of the path is a purification trough (temizuya) where visitors cleanse themselves and the office that administrates the shrine (shamusho).

sen.j: 大きな神社では神池や神橋がある場合もある。
sen.e: Larger shrines may have a sacred lake or bridge.
Larger shrines may have a sacred lake or bridge.
Larger shrines may have a sacred lake or bridge.

sen.j: 社殿は一般に本殿（神殿）・拝殿からなる。
sen.e: In most cases a shrine will be comprised of a main hall and a worship hall.
sen.cmt: 本殿、拝殿：英辞郎 on the WEB、およびhttp://nipponkichi.jp/article_list.do;jsessionid=FCAAB0B08AFFE3CCF0F6845722296C8D?kwd=4898&ml_lang=en
sen.e: In most cases a shrine will be comprised of a main hall and a worship hall.
In most cases a shrine will be comprised of a main hall and a worship hall.

sen.j: 人々がふだん参拝するときに目にするのは拝殿で、神体が安置される本殿は拝殿の奥にある。
sen.e: Ordinarily, people visiting the shrine will only be able to see the worship hall as the main hall that enshrines the object in which the kami resides is hidden behind the worship hall.
Ordinarily, people visiting the shrine will only be able to see the worship hall as the main hall that enshrines the object in which the kami resides is hidden behind the worship hall.
Ordinarily, people visiting the shrine will only be able to see the worship hall. The main hall, which enshrines the object in which the kami resides, is hidden behind the worship hall.
sen.cmt: I can't really see anything wrong with the original translation so it's a little dificult to know how I should rewrite this.

sen.j: 本殿と拝殿の間に参詣者が幣帛を供えるための幣殿が設置されていることもある。
sen.e: Some shrines have a hall of offerings (heiden) between the main hall and worship hall where worshippers can make offerings.
Some shrines have a hall of offerings (heiden) between the main hall and worship hall where worshippers can make offerings.
Some shrines have a hall of offerings (heiden) between the main hall and worship hall where worshippers can make offerings.

sen.j: 神社の敷地（境内）には、その神社の祭神に関係のある神や元々その土地に祀られていた神を祀る摂社や、それ以外の神を祀る末社があり、両者をあわせて摂末社と総称する。
sen.e: The grounds of a shrine contain both sessha (auxiliary shrines), dedicated to a deities closely related to that of the main shrine or a kami that was originally enshrined on the site, and massha (subordinate shrines), which are collectively known as 'Setsumatsusha'.

The grounds of a shrine contain both sessha (auxiliary shrines), dedicated to deities closely related to that of the main shrine or a kami that was originally enshrined on the site, and massha (subordinate shrines), which are collectively known as 'Setsumatsusha'.

The grounds of a shrine contain both sessha (auxiliary shrines), dedicated to deities closely related to that of the main shrine or a kami that was originally enshrined on the site, and massha (subordinate shrines), dedicated to deities other than above mentioned, which are collectively known as 'Setsumatsusha'.
sen.cmt: それ以外の神を祀る：訳抜け

sen.j: 境内の外に摂末社がある場合もあり、それは境外社と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Setsumatsusha may also lie outside of the grounds of the shrine, in which case they are referred to as 'keigaisha'.
Setsumatsusha may also lie outside of the grounds of the shrine, in which case they are referred to as 'keigaisha'.
Setsumatsusha may also lie outside of the grounds of the shrine, in which case they are referred to as 'keigaisha.'

sen.j: また、神仏習合が始まる奈良時代には神社の境内に神を供養する神宮寺（別当寺、宮寺）が建てられるようになった。
sen.e: The syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism that began during the Nara Period led to Jingu-ji (Betto-ji, Gu-ji [Miya-dera]) temples being constructed within Shinto shrines. This practice continued until early in the Meiji Period when the Meiji Government's ordinance distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism resulted in the separtion of Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples, the removal of five-story pagodas and Buddhist temples from within shrines and the differentiation between Buddhist and Shinto priests.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処神仏習合：英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism that began during the Nara Period led to Jingu-ji (Betto-ji, Gu-ji [Miya-dera]) temples being constructed within Shinto shrines.
sen.cmt: セル35を作り、trans 1を分割。原文も訂正。
sen.e: The syncretization of Shinto and Buddhism that began during the Nara Period led to Jingu-ji (Betto-ji, Gu-ji [Miya-dera]) temples being constructed within Shinto shrines.

sen.j: それ以後、神社内に寺院が建てられることもあったが、明治初期の明治政府による神仏判然令（神仏分離令）により、神社と寺院は分離され、神社境内にあった五重塔や仏堂などは撤去され、僧侶と神官も区別された。
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処明治政府、五重塔、仏堂、僧侶、神官：英辞郎 on the WEB神仏判然令：http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=826
sen.e: This practice continued until early in the Meiji Period when the Meiji Government's ordinance distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism resulted in the separation of Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples, the removal of five-story pagodas and Buddhist temples from within shrines and the differentiation between Buddhist and Shinto priests.

This practice continued until early in the Meiji Period when the Meiji Government's ordinance distinguishing Shinto and Buddhism resulted in the separation of Shinto shrines and Buddhist temples, the removal of five-story pagodas and Buddhist temples from within shrines and the differentiation between Buddhist and Shinto priests.

sen.j: 鳴き竜で有名な日光の東照宮本地堂（輪王寺薬師堂）は、東照宮と輪王寺の間で帰属が争われているという。
sen.e: Ownership of Nikko City's Tosho-gu Honjido (Rinno-ji Yakushido), famous for its Nakiryu (roaring dragon) ceiling painting, is said to be disputed by Tosho-gu Shrine and Rinno-ji Temple.

Ownership of Nikko City's Tosho-gu Shrine Honjido Hall (Rinno-ji Temple Yakushido Hall), famous for its Nakiryu (roaring dragon) ceiling painting and flutter echo is said to be disputed by Tosho-gu Shrine and Rinno-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: Tosho-gu Honjido→Tosho-gu Shrine Honjido Hall Rinno-ji Yakushido→Rinno-ji Temple Yakushido Hall鳴き竜→a flutter echo: 天井や床、平行な壁の間等で手を叩くと、多重反響現象によって特有の残響が聞こえるもの。天井に竜を描いた日光輪王寺薬師堂等が有名なところから、この現象一般を言う。
sen.e: Ownership of Nikko City's Tosho-gu Shrine Honjido Hall (Rinno-ji Temple Yakushido Hall), famous for its Nakiryu (roaring dragon) ceiling painting and flutter echo is said to be disputed by Tosho-gu Shrine and Rinno-ji Temple.

sen.j: 狛犬
sen.e: Guardian lion-dog statues (komainu)

sen.j: 眷属
sen.e: Messenger of the gods (Kenzoku)
Messenger of the gods (Kenzoku)
Messenger of the gods (Kenzoku)

sen.j: 概ね木造の日本式建築であるが、鉄筋コンクリート造が増えている。
sen.e: These are generally Japanese style wooden buildings but reinforced concrete structures are becoming increasingly common.
These are generally Japanese style wooden buildings but reinforced concrete structures are becoming increasingly common.
These are generally Japanese style wooden buildings but reinforced concrete structures are becoming increasingly common.

sen.j: 前述のようにビルの中にある神社もあるので、かならず建物が日本風というわけではない。
sen.e: As stated above, shrines may exist within other buildings so their structure may not necessarily of a Japanese style.
As stated above, shrines may exist within other buildings so their structure may not necessarily of a Japanese style.
As stated above, shrines may exist within other buildings so their structure may not necessarily of a Japanese style.

sen.j: ただし、御神体が安置される本殿の形は日本式建築である。
sen.e: However, the main hall enshrining the object in which the kami resides will be of a traditional Japanese style.
However, the main hall enshrining the object in which the kami resides will be of a traditional Japanese style.
However, the main hall enshrining the object in which the kami resides will be of a traditional Japanese style.

sen.j: 神社は夜間は警備の目が行き届かないところもあり、放火事件も発生している。
sen.e: During the night, there will be areas of a shrine that cannot be seen by security personnell and there have been incidents of arson.
During the night, there will be areas of a shrine that cannot be seen by security personnel and there have been incidents of arson.
During the night, there will be areas of a shrine that cannot be seen by security personnel and there have been incidents of arson.

sen.j: そのため、一部の神社では警備会社と契約して機械警備を行っている。
sen.e: For this reason, some shrines have entered into contracts with security firms to provide automated security systems.
For this reason, some shrines have entered into contracts with security firms to provide automated security systems.
For this reason, some shrines have entered into contracts with security firms to provide automated security systems.

sen.j: 防火や盗賊除けの神様が鎮座する神社に警備会社のステッカーが貼ってあるのを見かけることも多くなった。
sen.e: There are many Shrines enshrining gods of fire and theft prevention where security firm stickers can be seen.
There are many shrines enshrining gods of fire and theft prevention where security firm stickers can be seen.
There are many shrines enshrining gods of fire and theft prevention where security firm stickers can be seen.

sen.j: 現在は包括的な法整備によって神道は宗教法人に属しているが、本来の姿は宗教ではなく、自然や環境の保護や感謝、生に対する敬意を奉るものである。
sen.e: Shinto is now recognised as a religious organization according to comprehensive legislation but it was originally not a religion but rather a set of beliefs regarding the protection of and gratitude for nature and the environment and reverence for life.

Shinto is now recognised as a religious organization according to comprehensive legislation but it was originally not a religion but rather a set of beliefs regarding the protection of and gratitude for nature and the environment and reverence for life.

Shinto is now recognized as a religious organization according to comprehensive legislation but it was originally not a religion but rather a set of beliefs regarding the protection of and gratitude for nature and the environment and reverence for life.

sen.j: そのため、神職は他の宗教と違って宗教者ではなく、あくまでも神に対する奉仕者である。
sen.e: Therefore Shinto priests are different from those of other religions and serve in a role more akin to that of servants to the gods as opposed to religious leaders.
Therefore Shinto priests are different from those of other religions and serve in a role more akin to that of servants to the gods as opposed to religious leaders.
Therefore Shinto priests are different from those of other religions and serve in a role more akin to that of servants to the gods as opposed to religious leaders.

sen.j: 神社祭祀の担い手は神職（神主、宮司、禰宜、権禰宜など）と呼ばれる奉仕者だが、仏教やキリスト教などの宗教者と違って布教的性格をもたないのが一般的である。
sen.e: The person in charge of shrine rituals is the minister (priest, chief priest, senior priest, acting senior priest etc.) but, unlike a Christian or Buddhist priest, does generally not proselytize.
sen.cmt: Reformed broken sentence.仏教：英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: The person in charge of shrine rituals is the Shinto priesthood (priest, chief priest, senior priest, acting senior priest etc.) but, unlike a Christian or Buddhist priest, does generally not propagate.
sen.cmt: セル82と83の原文をつなげ、一つにまとめました。神職→the Shinto priesthood 原文に布教、とあるのでproselytize→propagate
sen.e: The person in charge of shrine rituals is the Shinto priesthood (priest, chief priest, senior priest, acting senior priest etc.) but, unlike a Christian or Buddhist priest, does generally not propagate.

sen.j: 従来、小規模な神社では専属の神職がいることは少なく、氏神が神社を建て、交替で管理し、神職を呼んで祭祀を行っていた。
sen.e: Traditionally, most small shrines built to honor an ujigami did not have their own priest but were managed alternately and a priest would be called in to perform rituals.
Traditionally, most small shrines built to honor an ujigami did not have their own priest but were managed alternately and a priest would be called in to perform rituals.
Traditionally, most small shrines built to honor an ujigami did not have their own priest but were managed alternately and a priest would be called in to perform rituals.

sen.j: また、神宮寺があった場合は神宮寺の僧が管理、祭祀を行なっていた。
sen.e: In the case that a shrine also contained a Buddhist temple, management and ceremonies would be carried out by the Buddhist priest.
In the case that a shrine also contained a Buddhist temple, management and ceremonies would be carried out by the Buddhist priest.
In the case that a shrine also contained a Buddhist temple, management and ceremonies would be carried out by the Buddhist priest.

sen.j: 現在、神職になるには、一般大学において神道を専攻して資格を取得した後、卒業しなければならない。
sen.e: It is now generally the case that anyone wishing to become a Shinto priest must graduate from university with a major in Shinto.
It is now generally the case that anyone wishing to become a Shinto priest must graduate from university with a major in Shinto.
It is now generally the case that anyone wishing to become a Shinto priest must graduate from university with a major in Shinto.

sen.j: 卒業後に全国の神社において研修（インターン制度）があるため、資格を取得していても、卒業をしていなければ神職にはなれない。
sen.e: After graduation, candidates must undergo training (internship scheme) at shrines around the country and so it is vital that they have graduated even if in possession of the proper qualifications.
After graduation, candidates must undergo training (internship scheme) at shrines around the country and so it is vital that they have graduated even if in possession of the proper qualifications.
After graduation, candidates must undergo training (internship scheme) at shrines around the country and so it is vital that they have graduated even if in possession of the proper qualifications.

sen.j: 祭祀対象は主に神道の神 (神道)であり、日本古来の神に属さない民俗神、実在の人物や伝説昔話の人物、仏教の神仏や道教の神などの外来の神も含まれている。
sen.e: Shinto mainly involves the worship of kami but also includes ethnic gods separate from Japan's ancient gods, actual people, characters from folklore, Buddhist deities and Taoist deities.
Shinto mainly involves the worship of kami but also includes ethnic gods separate from Japan's ancient gods, actual people, characters from folklore, Buddhist deities and Taoist deities.
Shinto mainly involves the worship of kami but also includes ethnic gods separate from Japan's ancient gods, actual people, characters from folklore, Buddhist deities and Taoist deities.

sen.j: 神社の名称の名付けられ方にはいくつか種類がある。
sen.e: Shrines are named according to a number of conventions.
Shrines are named according to a number of conventions.
Shrines are named according to a number of conventions.

sen.j: もっとも一般的なのは地名である。
sen.e: The most common of these is based on the name of its location.
The most common of these is based on the name of its location.
The most common of these is based on the name of its location.

sen.j: 鹿島神宮・八坂神社・春日神社・宗像神社・日枝神社などはいずれもそうである。
sen.e: Examples of shrines named for their location include Kashima-jingu Shrine, Yasaka-jinja Shrine, Kasuga-jinja Shrine, Munakata Taisha Shrine and Hie-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 「宗像神社」を「宗像大社」に訂正
sen.e: Examples of shrines named for their location include Kashima-jingu Shrine, Yasaka-jinja Shrine, Kasuga-jinja Shrine, Munakata Taisha Shrine and Hie-jinja Shrine.
Examples of shrines named for their location include Kashima-jingu Shrine, Yasaka-jinja Shrine, Kasuga-jinja Shrine, Munakata Taisha Shrine and Hie-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 「～坐神社」というのもある。
sen.e: Locational shrine names may also end with 'ni imasu jinja'.
Locational shrine names may also end with 'ni imasu jinja'.
Locational shrine names may also end with 'ni imasu jinja.'

sen.j: また祭神名を冠するものも多い。
sen.e: In addition, many shrine names begin with the name of the enshrined deity.
In addition, many shrine names begin with the name of the enshrined deity.
In addition, many shrine names begin with the name of the enshrined deity.

sen.j: 稲荷神社・住吉神社・八幡神社・天満宮・丹生都比売神社などが挙げられる。
sen.e: These include examples such as Inari-jinja Shrine, Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, Hachiman-jinja Shrine, Temman-gu Shrine and Niutsuhime-jinja Shrine.
These include examples such as Inari-jinja Shrine, Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, Hachiman-jinja Shrine, Temman-gu Shrine and Niutsuhime-jinja Shrine.
These include examples such as Inari-jinja Shrine, Sumiyoshi-jinja Shrine, Hachiman-jinja Shrine, Temman-gu Shrine and Niutsuhime-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: ほかに奉斎する氏族の名前を冠するもの（倭文神社）や祭神に関連する語句を冠するもの（平安神宮・八重垣神社）、神社の種別を表すもの（招魂社・祖霊社）・祭神の座数によるもの（六所宮・四柱神社）などがある。
sen.e: Other naming conventions for shrines include names beginning with the name of the family that enshrined the deity (e.g. Shitori-jinja Shrine), names beginning with words related to the enshrined deity (e.g. Heian-jingu Shrine, Yaegaki-jinja Shrine), names indicating the type of shrine (e.g Shokon-sha Shrine, Sorei-sha Shrine), and names indicating the number of enshrined deities (e.g. Rokusho-gu Shrine, Yohashira-jinja Shrine).

Other naming conventions for shrines include names beginning with the name of the family that enshrined the deity (e.g. Shitori-jinja Shrine), names beginning with words related to the enshrined deity (e.g. Heian-jingu Shrine, Yaegaki-jinja Shrine), names indicating the type of shrine (e.g Shokon-sha Shrine, Sorei-sha Shrine), and names indicating the number of enshrined deities (e.g. Rokusho-gu Shrine, Yohashira-jinja Shrine).

Other naming conventions for shrines include names beginning with the name of the family that enshrined the deity (e.g. Shitori-jinja Shrine), names beginning with words related to the enshrined deity (e.g. Heian-jingu Shrine, Yaegaki-jinja Shrine), names indicating the type of shrine (e.g. Shokon-sha Shrine, Sorei-sha Shrine), and names indicating the number of enshrined deities (e.g. Rokusho-gu Shrine, Yohashira-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: また由来のよく分からない神社名も少なく無い（浅間神社）。
sen.e: There are also a great many shrines for which the origin of the name is unknown (e.g. Sengen-jinja Shrine).
There are also a great many shrines for which the origin of the name is unknown (e.g. Sengen-jinja Shrine).
There are also a great many shrines for which the origin of the name is unknown (e.g. Sengen-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: 稲荷神社や八幡宮など全国に広く分布するものは、それらの社名にさらに地名を冠することが多い（伏見稲荷大社・函館八幡宮）。
sen.e: In cases, such as Inari-jinja Shrine and Hachiman-gu Shrine, where there are many shrines with the same name, the place name is often added onto the shrine name (e.g. Fushimi Inari-jinja Shrine, Hakodate Hachiman-gu Shrine).

In cases, such as Inari-jinja Shrine and Hachiman-gu Shrine, where there are many shrines with the same name, the place name is often added onto the shrine name (e.g. Fushimi Inari-jinja Shrine, Hakodate Hachiman-gu Shrine).

In cases, such as Inari-jinja Shrine and Hachiman-gu Shrine, where there are many shrines with the same name, the place name is often added onto the shrine name (e.g. Fushimi Inari-jinja Shrine, Hakodate Hachiman-gu Shrine).

sen.j: 天満宮は音読みで、八幡宮や浅間神社は音読みと訓読みの場合がある。
sen.e: The name of Temman-gu Shrine is pronounced according to the Sino-Japanese reading of Japanese characters, whereas the names of Hachiman-gu Shrine and Sengen-jinja Shrine can be pronounced according to either the Sino-Japanese or native Japanese reading. However these Sino-Japanese pronunciations for shrine names only arose due to the influece of Buddhism.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The name of Temman-gu Shrine is pronounced according to the Sino-Japanese reading of Japanese characters, whereas the names of Hachiman-gu Shrine and Sengen-jinja Shrine can be pronounced according to either the Sino-Japanese or native Japanese reading.
sen.cmt: セル108を作り、trans 1を分割。原文も訂正。
sen.e: The name of Temman-gu Shrine is pronounced according to the Sino-Japanese reading of Japanese characters, whereas the names of Hachiman-gu Shrine and Sengen-jinja Shrine can be pronounced according to either the Sino-Japanese or native Japanese reading.

sen.j: 音読みで社号を読むのは仏教の影響である。
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However these Sino-Japanese pronunciations for shrine names only arose due to the influece of Buddhism.
However these Sino-Japanese pronunciations for shrine names only arose due to the influence of Buddhism.

sen.j: 天満宮はそのもととなった天満天神の祭神名自体が仏教の影響を受けているため、漢語の社名となっている。
sen.e: Temman-gu Shrine was given a Sino-Japanese name as the name of the enshrined deity 'Tenman Tenjin' itself was influenced by Buddhism.
Temman-gu Shrine was given a Sino-Japanese name as the name of the enshrined deity 'Tenman Tenjin' itself was influenced by Buddhism.
Temman-gu Shrine was given a Sino-Japanese name as the name of the enshrined deity 'Tenman Tenjin' itself was influenced by Buddhism.

sen.j: 八幡宮と浅間神社はいずれも元来は「やわた」「あさま」と訓読みしたものであったが、神仏習合のもと仏教の影響で、音読みが定着することとなった。
sen.e: Hachiman-gu Shrine and Sengen-jinja Shrine were originally pronounced 'Yawata-gu' and 'Asama-gu' respectively, but the syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism and the influence of Buddhism led to the Sino-Japanese pronunciation becoming established.

Hachiman-gu Shrine and Sengen-jinja Shrine were originally pronounced 'Yawata-gu' and 'Asama-jinja' respectively, but the syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism and the influence of Buddhism led to the Sino-Japanese pronunciation becoming established.

Hachiman-gu Shrine and Sengen-jinja Shrine were originally pronounced 'Yawata-gu' and 'Asama-jinja' respectively, but the syncretization of Shinto with Buddhism and the influence of Buddhism led to the Sino-Japanese pronunciation becoming established.

sen.j: 神社名において注意すべき点として、次のことがある。
sen.e: Points to be aware of regarding shine names are a follows.
Points to be aware of regarding shine names are a follows.
Points to be aware of regarding shrine names are a follows.

sen.j: 原則として全ての神社を「～神社」（宮号・神宮号を除く）と称するようになったのは近代になってから、ということである。
sen.e: Generally, referring to all shrines with the siffix 'jinja' is a fairly recent development.
Generally, referring to all shrines with the suffix 'jinja' (except the suffix 'gu' and 'jingu') is a fairly recent development.
Generally, referring to all shrines with the suffix 'jinja' (except the suffix 'gu' and 'jingu') is a fairly recent development.

sen.j: 「～明神」や「～権現」などと神名をもって社号としていたところや、もしくは「～稲荷」「～八幡」と「神社」の部分が省略されていたところ、「～社」としていたところなどがあったが、全て原則として「～神社」と称することになったのである。
sen.e: Shrines with a title such as '-myojin' or '-gongen', those for which the '-Inari', '-Hachiman' or 'jinja' part could be abbreviated, or those for which '-sha' was suffixed are now all generally referred to with the suffix '-jinja'.

Shrines with a title such as '-myojin' or '-gongen', those for which the '-inari', '-hachiman' and 'jinja' part was abbreviated, or those for which '-sha' was suffixed are now all generally referred to with the suffix '-jinja'.
sen.cmt: -Inari'→'-inari''-Hachiman'→'-hachiman' ※他と表現を統一する為に小文字にしました。or 'jinja' part could be abbreviated→and 'jinja' part was abbreviated
sen.e: Shrines with a title such as '-myojin' or '-gongen,' those for which the '-inari,' '-hachiman' and 'jinja' part was abbreviated, or those for which '-sha' was suffixed are now all generally referred to with the suffix '-jinja.'
sen.cmt: カンマ、ピリオドの位置移動

sen.j: これを権現号の使用禁止と関連させて、排仏政策によるものだという指摘もあるが、それよりはむしろ国家管理の施設としての合理化によるものといえるだろう。
sen.e: This trend can be linked to prohibition of the use of the 'gongen' title and there are also indications that it is partially a due to the anti-Buddhist movement, but it is far more likely to be a result of the streamlining that arose as a result of the status of shrines as nationally managed institutions.

This trend can be linked to prohibition of the use of the 'gongen' title and there are also indications that it is partially a due to the anti-Buddhist movement, but it is far more likely to be a result of the streamlining that arose as a result of the status of shrines as nationally managed institutions.

This trend can be linked to prohibition of the use of the 'gongen' title and there are also indications that it is partially due to the anti-Buddhist movement, but it is far more likely to be a result of the streamlining that arose as a result of the status of shrines as nationally managed institutions.
sen.cmt: a due to のa 不要

sen.j: 終戦まで近代においては神社はいわば国家の施設であり、当然法令上の規則があって、神社と認められるには備えるべき設備や財産などの条件があり、それ以外は「神社」とは認められなかったのである。
sen.e: Until the end of the war, shrines were essentially national institutions with regulations that dictated conditions regarding facilities and assets that had to be met in order to be recognized as a shrine.

Until the end of the war, shrines were essentially national institutions with regulations that dictated conditions regarding facilities and assets that had to be met in order to be recognized as a shrine.

sen.j: 社号
sen.e: Shrine Titles (shogo)
Shrine Titles (shago)
Shrine Titles (shago)

sen.j: 神社の中でも、規模の大きい神社は神宮や大社と呼ばれ、有名な神を祭神とする場合が多い。
sen.e: Larger shrines are referred to as 'jingu' or 'taisha' and often enshrine well-known kami.
Larger shrines are referred to as 'jingu' or 'taisha' and often enshrine well-known kami.
Larger shrines are referred to as 'jingu' or 'taisha' and often enshrine well-known kami.

sen.j: なお、天皇や皇室祖先神を祭神とする神社を神宮と呼ぶことが多く、天皇家につながる人物（皇族）を祭神とする神社を宮と呼ぶことが多い。
sen.e: Shrines that enshrine emperors or imperial ancestors are often referred to as 'jingu' and those that enshrine a member of the imperial household are commonly entitled 'gu'.
Shrines that enshrine emperors or imperial ancestors are often referred to as 'jingu' and those that enshrine a member of the imperial household are commonly entitled 'gu'.
Shrines that enshrine emperors or imperial ancestors are often referred to as 'jingu' and those that enshrine a member of the imperial household are commonly entitled 'gu.'

sen.j: 大社は前近代には杵築大社（現出雲大社）・熊野大社（いずれも島根県）しか名乗っていないが、戦前は出雲大社のみが大社を名乗っていた。
sen.e: In premodern times, only Kitsuki Taisha Shrine (Izumo Taisha Shrine) and Kumano Taisha Shrine (both in Shimane Prefecture) bore the shogo 'Taisha', but by the pre-war period Izumo Taisha Shrine was the only one to do so.

In premodern times, only Kitsuki Taisha Shrine (Izumo Taisha Shrine) and Kumano Taisha Shrine (both in Shimane Prefecture) bore the shogo 'taisha', but by the pre-war period Izumo Taisha Shrine was the only one to do so.

In premodern times, only Kitsuki Taisha Shrine (presently Izumo Taisha Shrine) and Kumano Taisha Shrine (both in Shimane Prefecture) bore the shrine name 'taisha,' but by the pre-war period Izumo Taisha Shrine was the only one to do so.
sen.cmt: The term "shogo" is defined immediately above but as it is given in parentheses after the English translation, it makes sense to use the English here, I think.

sen.j: 戦後は旧官幣大社・国幣大社・官幣中社の神社の一部が大社を名乗っている。
sen.e: Following the end of the war, Kampei Taisha Shrine, Kokuhei Taisha Shrine and Kampei Chusha Shrine adopted the shogo 'Taisha'.
Following the end of the war, former Kampei Taisha Shrine, Kokuhei Taisha Shrine and Kampei Chusha Shrine adopted the shogo 'taisha'.
Following the end of the war, former Kampei Taisha Shrine, Kokuhei Taisha Shrine and Kampei Chusha Shrine adopted the shogo 'taisha.'

sen.j: 1945年以前は神宮などを名乗るためには勅許などが必要だったが、現在では政教分離原則により国家、皇室が神社に直接関与しなくなったため、特に許可を受けなくても、大社、神宮を名乗ることができる。
sen.e: Prior to 1945, it was necessary to obtain permission in order to adopt a shogo such as 'jingu' but the separation of politics and religion means that now neither the government nor the imperial household are able to become directly involved and shrines can adopt the title of 'Taisha' or 'jingu' without requiring any special permission.

Prior to 1945, it was necessary to obtain imperial permission in order to adopt a shogo such as 'jingu' but the separation of politics and religion means that now neither the government nor the imperial household are able to become directly involved and shrines can adopt the title of 'taisha' or 'jingu' without requiring any special permission.

Prior to 1945, it was necessary to obtain imperial permission in order to adopt a shogo such as 'jingu' but the separation of politics and religion means that now neither the government nor the imperial household are able to become directly involved and shrines can adopt the title of 'taisha' or 'jingu' without requiring any special permission.

sen.j: 現在、大社を名乗っている神社は上記の二社のほか、気多大社（石川県）、諏訪大社（長野県）、南宮大社（岐阜県）、三嶋大社・富士山本宮浅間大社（静岡県）、多度大社（三重県）、日吉大社・多賀大社・建部大社（滋賀県）、松尾大社・伏見稲荷大社（京都府）、住吉大社（大阪府）、春日大社・龍田大社・広瀬大社（奈良県）、熊野本宮大社・熊野速玉大社・熊野那智大社（和歌山県）、宗像大社・高良大社（福岡県）などがある。
sen.e: In addition to the two examples given above, the other shrines that currently carry the shogo of 'Taisha' include Kita Taisha Shrine (Ishikawa Prefecture), Suwa Taisha Shrine (Nagano Prefecture), Nangu Taisha Shrine (Gifu Prefecture), Mishima Taisha Shrine/Fujisan Hongu Sengen Taisha Shrine (Shizuoka Prefecture), Tado Taisha Shrine (Mie Prefecture), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine/Taga Taisha Shrine/Takebe Taisha Shrine (Shiga Prefecture), Matsuo Taisha Shrine/Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine (Kyoto Prefecture), Sumiyoshi Taisha Shrine (Osaka Prefecture), Kasuga Taisha Shrine/Tatsuta Taisha Shrine/Hirose Taisha Shrine (Nara Prefecture), Kumano Hongu Taisha Shrine/Kumano Hayatama Taisha Shrine/Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine (Wakatama Prefecture), Munakata Taisha Shrine/Kora Taisha Shrine (Fukuoka Prefecture).

In addition to the two examples given above, the other shrines that currently carry the shogo of 'taisha' include Kita Taisha Shrine (Ishikawa Prefecture), Suwa Taisha Shrine (Nagano Prefecture), Nangu Taisha Shrine (Gifu Prefecture), Mishima Taisha Shrine/Fujisan Hongu Sengen Taisha Shrine (Shizuoka Prefecture), Tado Taisha Shrine (Mie Prefecture), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine/Taga Taisha Shrine/Takebe Taisha Shrine (Shiga Prefecture), Matsuo Taisha Shrine/Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine (Kyoto Prefecture), Sumiyoshi Taisha Shrine (Osaka Prefecture), Kasuga Taisha Shrine/Tatsuta Taisha Shrine/Hirose Taisha Shrine (Nara Prefecture), Kumano Hongu Taisha Shrine/Kumano Hayatama Taisha Shrine/Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine (Wakayama Prefecture), Munakata Taisha Shrine/Kora Taisha Shrine (Fukuoka Prefecture).

In addition to the two examples given above, the other shrines that currently carry the shogo of 'taisha' include Kita Taisha Shrine (Ishikawa Prefecture), Suwa Taisha Shrine (Nagano Prefecture), Nangu Taisha Shrine (Gifu Prefecture), Mishima Taisha Shrine/Fujisan Hongu Sengen Taisha Shrine (Shizuoka Prefecture), Tado Taisha Shrine (Mie Prefecture), Hiyoshi Taisha Shrine/Taga Taisha Shrine/Takebe Taisha Shrine (Shiga Prefecture), Matsuo Taisha Shrine/Fushimi Inari Taisha Shrine (Kyoto Prefecture), Sumiyoshi Taisha Shrine (Osaka Prefecture), Kasuga Taisha Shrine/Tatsuta Taisha Shrine/Hirose Taisha Shrine (Nara Prefecture), Kumano Hongu Taisha Shrine/Kumano Hayatama Taisha Shrine/Kumano Nachi Taisha Shrine (Wakayama Prefecture), Munakata Taisha Shrine/Kora Taisha Shrine (Fukuoka Prefecture).

sen.j: また、梅宮大社（京都府）や大鳥大社（大阪府）のように表記が定まっていないものもある。
sen.e: In addition, there are shrines such as Umenomiya Taisha Shrine (Kyoto Prefecture) and Otori Taisha Shrine (Osaka Prefecture) for which the denotation is not set.

sen.j: また平野神社（京都府）もかつては扁額に「平野大社」と書かれていた。
sen.e: Moreover, the name plate on the torii of Hirano-jinja Shrine (Osaka Prefecture) reads 'Hirano Taisha'.

sen.j: 戦後になって新たに神宮を名乗るようになった神社には北海道神宮（旧札幌神社・北海道）、伊弉諾神宮（兵庫県）、英彦山神宮（福岡県）がある（京都府亀岡市の元官幣中社出雲大神宮等の「大神宮」は「神宮」号とは異なるものの解されている）。
sen.e: The shrines that changed their names after the end of the war are Hokkaido-jingu Shrine (previously Sapporo-jinja Shrine, Hokkaido), Izanagi-jingu Shrine (Hyogo Prefecture) and Hikosan-jingu Shrine (those with the name 'Daijingu' such as Fukuoka Prefecture) (the 'Dai-jingu' shogo of shrines such as Izumo Dai-jingu Shrine, formerly Kampei Chusha, in Kameoka City, Kyoto Prefecture are recognised as being different from the 'jingu' shogo.

sen.j: 福岡県福岡市東区 (福岡市)の香椎宮はいわゆる神宮ではないが、最寄り駅が香椎神宮駅（香椎線）というため、誤解される例もある。

sen.j: 主な信仰
sen.e: Main Beliefs
Main Beliefs
Main Beliefs

sen.j: 多くの神社では、有名な神社から祭神を勧請（かんじょう）している。
sen.e: Many shrines transfer in deities from famous shrines.
Many shrines transfer in deities from famous shrines.
Many shrines transfer in deities from famous shrines.

sen.j: 勧請とは、祭神の分霊を他の神社に招いて祀ることである。
sen.e: This involves dividing a shrine's tutelary deity and enshrining it in another shrine.
This involves dividing a shrine's tutelary deity and enshrining it in another shrine.
This involves dividing a shrine's tutelary deity and enshrining it in another shrine.

sen.j: ロウソクからロウソクへ灯をうつすように、神道の神は無限に分霊することができ、分霊しても本来の神威が損なわれることがないとされている。
sen.e: In the same way that a lantern can be lit from a candle, a Shinto kami can be infinitely divided without causing any harm to the original deity.
In the same way that a candle can be lit from a candle, a Shinto kami can be infinitely divided without causing any harm to the original deity.
In the same way that a candle can be lit from a candle, a Shinto kami can be infinitely divided without causing any harm to the original deity.

sen.j: 勧請した神社は、その祭神に応じた名称がつけられ、同一の祭神を祀る（同一の名称の）神社同士は系列神社と呼ばれる。
sen.e: The shrine that made the invitation is given a name according to the enshrined deity that is the same as that of the shrine from which it came and the two then become linked shrines.
The shrine that made the invitation is given a name according to the enshrined deity that is the same as that of the shrine from which it came and the two then become linked shrines.
The shrine that made the invitation is given a name according to the enshrined deity that is the same as that of the shrine from which it came and the two then become linked shrines.

sen.j: 以下に主な系列神社の名称とその祭神を挙げる。
sen.e: The following gives the major linked shrines and their enshrined kami.

sen.j: 中にはまれながら神社名と一般的な祭神が一致しない神社もある。
sen.e: There are shrines that have enshrined a deity but for which the shrine name and that of the kami do not match.
There are few shrines that have enshrined a deity but for which the shrine name and that of the kami do not match.

sen.j: また近代になって新造された靖国神社・招魂社（護国神社）のようなものもある。
sen.e: There are also recently constructed shrines such as Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Shokonsha (Gokoku-jinja Shrine).
There are also recently constructed shrines such as Yasukuni-jinja Shrine and Shokonsha Shrine (Gokoku-jinja Shrine).
